Most biological membranes contain a substantial amount of glycerophospholipids loosely called phospholipids, and a remarkable feature of these membrane phospholipids is their bewildering diversity. This diversity originates largely from the various possible combinations of different fatty acyl chains present in the hydrophobic moiety of the amphipathic phospholipid molecule. Specifically, the structures of the two fatty acids hydrolyzed enzymatically from animal phospholipids display the following general features. (i) With the possible exceptions of mammalian lung and nerve endings, which contain large amounts of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine(1Goerke J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1974; 344: 241-261Crossref PubMed Scopus (371) Google Scholar, 2O'Brien J.F. Geison R.L. J. Lipid Res. 1974; 15: 44-49Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), identical fatty acids in both acyl positions occur rarely in a naturally occurring phospholipid molecule. Instead, the two fatty acids have a different even number of carbon atoms ranging from 14 to 22(3Lands W.E.M. Hart P. J. Am. Oil Chem. Soc. 1966; 43: 290-295Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 4Tattrie N.H. Bennett J.R. Cyr R. Can. J. Biochem. 1968; 46: 819-824Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). (ii) The fatty acids in natural phospholipids are nonrandomly distributed. The one that is esterified to the hydroxyl group at glycerol backbone carbon 1, the sn-1 acyl chain, is often a saturated fatty acid, whereas the other, the sn-2 acyl chain, is predominantly an unsaturated one(3Lands W.E.M. Hart P. J. Am. Oil Chem. Soc. 1966; 43: 290-295Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). (iii) The unsaturated fatty acids derived from the sn-2 acyl chains of major membrane phospholipids in animal tissues have the structural formula CH3-(CH2) - [CH=CH-CH2] - (CH2) - COOH, where the subscripts α = 1, 4, 5, and 7, β = 1-6, and = 2-7, and the cis-double bonds (β = 1-6) are always separated by one methylene group(5Kunau W.-H. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. Engl. 1976; 15: 61-74Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Because of the large number of possible ways that permutations of chain length and unsaturation can occur, a given class of membrane phospholipids such as phosphatidylcholine isolated from a given cell type can be expected to give rise to a significant number of specific molecular species. Indeed, 57 molecular species of phosphatidylcholines have been detected in mammalian liver(6Myher J.J. Kuksis A. Can. J. Biochem. 1982; 60: 638-650Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar). Probably because of the large number of molecular species of natural phosphatidylcholines, the physical properties of most membrane phosphatidylcholines with mixed sn-1 saturated/sn-2 unsaturated acyl chains have not yet been fully established. The thermotropic phase transitions of phospholipid bilayers and their relevance to biological membranes, for instance, have been investigated extensively for nearly 3 decades(7Chapman D. William R.M. Ladbrook B.D. Chem. Phys. Lipids. 1967; 1: 445-475Crossref Scopus (781) Google Scholar, 8Chapman D. Shinitzky M. Biomembranes: Physical Aspects. Balaban Publishers, Weinheim, Germany1993: 29-62Google Scholar). Surprisingly, with the notable exception of 1-palmitoyl-2-oleoylphosphatidylcholine (9Curatolo W. Sears B. Neuringer L.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1985; 817: 261-270Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 10Coolbear K.P. Berde C.B. Keough K.M.W. Biochemistry. 1983; 22: 1466-1473Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 11Litman B.J. Lewis E.N. Levin I.W. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 313-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar) and a few other species (10Coolbear K.P. Berde C.B. Keough K.M.W. Biochemistry. 1983; 22: 1466-1473Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 11Litman B.J. Lewis E.N. Levin I.W. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 313-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar), only limited information is available regarding the phase transition behavior of most natural phosphatidylcholines. Clearly, a significantly rapid progress in this field is definitely needed. The role played by amphipathic phosphatidylcholines in biological membranes has, until recently, been viewed primarily as that of a structural component of biological membranes in eukaryotic cells. This picture is now changed drastically, since the breakdown components of phosphatidylcholine molecule, or the intermediates of the “phosphatidylcholine cycle,” in the cell membrane have turned out to be involved actively in signal transduction in response to extracellular stimuli(12Exton J.H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1212: 26-42Crossref PubMed Scopus (924) Google Scholar, 13Tronchere H. Record M. Tercé F. Chap H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1212: 137-151Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). In addition, there is increasing evidence suggesting that skeletal muscle phospholipids with polyunsaturated sn-2 acyl chains may be of great significance in modulating the insulin receptor activity(14Borkman M. Storlien L.H. Pan D.A. Jenkins A.B. Chisholm D.J. Champbell L.V. N. Engl. J. Med. 1993; 328: 238-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (781) Google Scholar, 15Liu S. Baracos V.E. Quinney H.A. Clandinin M.T. Biochem. J. 1994; 299: 831-837Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). In view of these recent exciting findings, it is important to study systematically the various natural phosphatidylcholines with well defined composition and to obtain information regarding the specific contributions of the characteristic unsaturated acyl chains to the structure and properties of the lipid bilayer comprised of natural phosphatidylcholines. As a first step to investigate systematically the physical properties of naturally occurring phosphatidylcholines with mixed sn-1 saturated/sn-2 unsaturated acyl chains, we have semisynthesized 26 molecular species of identical chain and mixed chain phosphatidylcholines, each containing a single cis-double bond in the sn-2 acyl chain. In this paper we report the phase transition characteristics of these molecular species as determined by high resolution differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). 1The abbreviations used are: DSCdifferential scanning calorimetryMMmolecular mechanicsTphase transition temperatureΔHtransition enthalpyEthe steric energy, in kcal/mol, of an energy-minimized lipid speciesC(X):C(Y)PCsaturated phosphatidylcholine or 1,2-diacyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine with X carbons in the sn-1 and Y carbons in the sn-2 acyl chainC(X):C(Y:1Δ)PCmonounsaturated phosphatidylcholine with a saturated sn-1 acyl chain containing X carbons and a monounsaturated sn-2 acyl chain containing Y carbons with a cis-carbon-carbon double bond (Δ) at the nth carbon atom from the carboxyl endΔTtransition peak width at half-heightPEphosphatidylethanolamineΔSphase transition entropy changeΔHweight average transition enthalpyF-Bfront to backU-Dup to down. Moreover, molecular mechanics (MM) calculations are applied to refine the three-dimensional structures and to compute the steric energies of several series of Δ bond-containing phosphatidylcholine molecules which, in turn, are used to account for the thermodynamic data. Finally, the phase transition temperatures (T) associated with the gel to liquid-crystalline phase transitions of bilayers prepared from two groups of a total of 26 monoenoic phosphatidylcholines are analyzed in terms of their structural parameters by a multiple regression approach, leading to the derivation of two general equations. It is of the greatest interest and significance that there is a common T-structure relationship that holds for most different monoenoic phosphatidylcholines within each group of the natural lipids. differential scanning calorimetry molecular mechanics phase transition temperature transition enthalpy the steric energy, in kcal/mol, of an energy-minimized lipid species saturated phosphatidylcholine or 1,2-diacyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine with X carbons in the sn-1 and Y carbons in the sn-2 acyl chain monounsaturated phosphatidylcholine with a saturated sn-1 acyl chain containing X carbons and a monounsaturated sn-2 acyl chain containing Y carbons with a cis-carbon-carbon double bond (Δ) at the nth carbon atom from the carboxyl end transition peak width at half-height phosphatidylethanolamine phase transition entropy change weight average transition enthalpy front to back up to down. Monounsaturated fatty acids with various chain lengths, each containing a cis-double bond at different positions, were purchased from Sigma. Lysophosphatidylcholines with various saturated acyl chain lengths were provided by Avanti Polar Lipids, Inc. (Alabaster, AL). Silica Gel 60 (mesh 230-400) was obtained from EM Science (Gibbtown, NJ). All chemicals and organic solvents were of reagent and spectroscopic grades, respectively. Monounsaturated phosphatidylcholines were semisynthesized at room temperature by acylation of CdCl2 adducts of lysophosphatidylcholine, in dry chloroform, with monounsaturated fatty acid anhydride that was prepared in situ from fatty acid and dicyclohexylcarbodiimide, in the presence of catalyst 4-pyrrolidinopyridine according to the modified procedure of Mena and Djerassi (16Mena P.L. Djerassi C. Chem. Phys. Lipids. 1985; 37: 257-270Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar) as described previously(17Lin H.-n. Wang Z.-q. Huang C. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 7063-7072Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). The in situ reaction and the reacylation were carried out under an N2 atmosphere to avoid the possible oxidation of the unsaturated fatty acid. The synthesized sn-1 saturated/sn-2 monounsaturated phosphatidylcholines were subsequently purified to about 99% purity by repeated column chromatography on Silica Gel 60(17Lin H.-n. Wang Z.-q. Huang C. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 7063-7072Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Purified monoenoic phosphatidylcholines were lyophilized from benzene before weighing. The lyophilized sample was then dispersed in buffered (pH 7.4) aqueous solution containing 50 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, and 5 mM phosphate buffer to give a final lipid concentration in the range of 3.0-6.0 mM. The exact lipid concentrations were determined by phosphorus analysis. Prior to DSC experiments, the lipid sample was kept in the cold room (0°C) overnight under an N2 atmosphere. DSC experiments were carried out with a high resolution Microcal calorimeter (model MC-2) equipped with DA-2 digital interface and data acquisition utility for automatic collection (Microcal, Northampton, MA). After loading the lipid sample into the sample cell of the calorimeter, it was preincubated in the calorimeter for a minimum of 60 min at the desired temperature (usually 15°C below the estimated Tm) followed by the DSC heating scan. The scan was terminated at about 15°C above the estimated Tm. The sample was then allowed to equilibrate thermally at the elevated temperature for 60 min prior to the cooling scan. Each sample was scanned at least five times: three heating and two cooling runs. In all of these experiments, a nominal scan rate of 15°C/h was used. The Tm and the transition enthalpy (ΔH) were determined, as described in(17Lin H.-n. Wang Z.-q. Huang C. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 7063-7072Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar), from the second and third heating curves, and the average values were reported for each sample. The MM2 force field (Version 85), written by Allinger (18Allinger N.L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1977; 99: 8127-8134Crossref Scopus (4127) Google Scholar) and supplied by Quantum Chemistry Program Exchange (Department of Chemistry, Indiana University), was chosen as the software for the MM calculations. All MM computations were run on an IBM RS/6000 computer workstation. The structural data from the output of the MM2 calculations were transferred and then displayed in the form of various two-dimensional representations of the three-dimensional molecular structure, which was accomplished by the computer-assisted molecular graphics using the software package HyperChem (Autodesk Inc., Sausalito, CA) performed on a 486 platform. Prior to MM calculations, a set of torsion angles for a crude representation of the molecule under study was first constructed. This starting set of atomic coordinates was entered, via the MM2 program, into the computer. An optimized structure corresponding to the minimum steric energy (Es) closest to the starting point was subsequently determined for the molecule by MM calculations using a set of potential energy functions (called force fields). These calculations involved a series of repeated automatic cycles of the second derivative Newton-Raphson method for energy minimizations. These cycles of self-adjusted computations came to a halt as the steric energy difference between two consecutive cycles was less than (0.00008 × molecular weight) kcal/mol. For the MM2 program, the steric energy has the following terms: Es = E+Eb+E+E+E+E, where E = bond stretch energy, Eb = bond angle bend energy, E = torsional energy, E = bond dipole interaction energy, E = van der Waals nonbonding interaction energy, E = coupling energy between bond stretching and bond bending. It should be emphasized that the absolute value of Es is of no great significance, since it depends on the software program used. When the same MM2 program is adopted, however, the Es values for a homologous series of positional isomers are quite useful for making relative comparisons. The initial crude structure of C(16):C(18:1Δ9)PC was constructed based on the energy-minimized structure of C(14):C(14)PC (19Li S. Wang Z.-q. Lin H.-n. Huang C. Biophys. J. 1993; 65: 1415-1428Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar), and the torsion angles of oleate chain of cholesteryl oleate were determined by x-ray diffraction(20Gao Q. Craven B.M. J. Lipid Res. 1986; 27: 1214-1221Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), as described previously(21Li S. Lin H.-n. Wang Z.-q. Huang C. Biophys. J. 1994; 66: 2005-2018Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Briefly, the torsion angles of the sn-2 acyl chain of C(16):C(18:1Δ9)PC starting from C(3) to the chain methyl terminus were taken from the crystal data of the cholesteryl oleate, and all other torsion angles of the lipid molecule were taken from the energy-minimized structure of C(14):C(14)PC except that the sn-1 acyl chain was extended by two methylene units in the trans form. This assembled structure was taken as the crude structure of C(16):C(18:1Δ9)PC. It was subsequently subjected to MM calculations in which the internal coordinates were modified by Allinger's MM2 program until a minimum in the potential energy surface was reached. The resulting structure was taken as the optimized or energy-minimized structure of C(16):C(18:1Δ9)PC. The torsion angles of the various bonds, most importantly those in the vicinity of the Δ bond, obtained with this optimized structure were used subsequently as the starting atomic coordinates to search for minimal energy structures of other monoenoic lipids with the Δ bond at different positions in the sn-2 acyl chain. For instance, the initial crude structure of C(18):C(18:1Δ)PC can be readily created by adding two methylene units in the trans form into the sn-1 acyl chain of C(16):C(18:1Δ9)PC and by moving the Δ bond to the Δ position in the sn-2 acyl chain. The refined three-dimensional energy-minimized structure of C(18):C(18:1Δ)PC can then be obtained by subjecting the crude structure to MM calculations using the MM2 program. Similarly, the same protocol can be used to obtain energy-minimized structures of other monoenoic phosphatidylcholines. However, when a Δ bond was introduced into the sn-2 acyl chain at an even carbon atom such as C(18):C(18:1Δ)PC, the initial values of the two torsion angles immediately preceding the Δ bond (1 and 2) and those (′1 and ′2) immediately succeeding the Δ bond in the sequence 21Δ′1′2 were assigned to be negative, although the absolute magnitudes of these torsion angles were still taken from those of the energy-minimized structure of C(16):C(18:1Δ9)PC. This change in sign was simply to reflect the fact that even and odd carbons in an all trans-acyl chains lie commonly on two opposite and parallel planes. In this paper, attempts have been made to compare the structures of various phosphatidylcholines. Since all of these lipid molecules have the same head group, being different in their diglyceride moieties only, we feel that it is justified to simplify our MM calculations by considering the diglyceride moieties of these lipid molecules only. Consequently, various sn-1 saturated/sn-2 unsaturated phosphatidylcholines without the headgroups are used exclusively for our MM calculations. In this approach, the headgroup-headgroup interactions are assumed to be identical, and the headgroup-diglyceride interactions are assumed to be small; hence, they are ignored when a relative comparison among phosphatidylcholines is made. Furthermore, the water molecules are considered to be excluded from the hydrophobic interior; hence, Allinger's MM2 calculations of the diglyceride moiety of the lipid molecule were performed in vacuo to avoid solvent interactions. For dimers and tetramers, the MM calculations were performed according to the same procedure as that used for the monomer, essentially as described in detail elsewhere(19Li S. Wang Z.-q. Lin H.-n. Huang C. Biophys. J. 1993; 65: 1415-1428Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Again, these aggregates are the aggregated diglyceride moieties of the lipid molecules. The DSC heating thermograms for aqueous dispersions of six isomers of C(18):C(18:1Δn)PC are presented in Fig. 1. These positional isomers with the same molecular weight have a common sn-1 acyl chain. In addition, each has only one cis-carbon-carbon double bond (Δ) in the sn-2 octadecenoyl chain. However, the position of the double bond from the carboxyl carbon of the acyl chain (Δn) is different, with n = 6, 7, 9, 11, 12, and 13. Each DSC heating thermogram shown in Fig. 1 is characterized by a sharp, single, nearly symmetrical, endothermic transition that is reproducible upon subsequent reheatings. The observed transition is assigned as the gel to liquid-crystalline phase transition or the chain melting transition. The Tm and ΔH associated with the chain melting transition for various isomers of C(18):C(18:1Δn)PC, in excess water, are summarized in Table 1. The Tm values obtained with the cooling exotherms (data not shown) of these lipid samples occur at temperatures that are either identical to or slightly lower (0.2-0.4°C) than the Tm values obtained with the heating endotherms.Table 1View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Open table in a new tab It is interesting to recognize from Fig. 1 that as the cis-double bond migrates from the carboxyl end toward the chain methyl terminus, the phase transition peaks are changed accordingly both in terms of the peak width and the position of the maximal peak height (Tm). Specifically, the transition peak width at half-height (ΔT) is seen to increase from 0.3 to 1.1°C as the position of the Δ bond (Δn) moves from C(6) to C(13); the Tm value decreases steadily from 24.8°C to a minimum value of 3.8°C as the Δ bond moves along the chain from C(6) to C(11) and then increases progressively from 3.8 to 15.9°C as the Δ bond moves further along the chain from C(11) to C(13). Most interestingly, the Tm values in the TmversusΔn plot shown in Fig. 2 can be fitted by the least squares procedure to a smooth parabolic curve with a correlation coefficient of 0.9951. In comparison, the ΔH values are, within experimental errors, relatively insensitive to the position of the Δ bond (Table 1), but a general trend similar to that of the Tm profile is evident. The least squares fitting curve in the TmversusΔn plot yields Δn = 10 and Tm = 3.8°C as the abscissa and ordinate of vertex, respectively, for monoenoic C(18):C(18:1Δn)PC (Fig. 2). The calorimetric Tm value for aqueous dispersion of saturated C(18):C(18)PC is 55.3°C(22Huang C. Wang Z. Lin H. Brumbaugh E.E. Li S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1189: 7-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). The calculated Tm value for C(18):C(18:1Δ)PC based on the coordinates of vertex of the best fit parabola shown in Fig. 2 is 3.8°C, corresponding to a significant drop in absolute temperature of 15.7%. However, as the Δ bond moves toward either end of the sn-2 acyl chain, the Tm-lowering effect is diminished considerably. The identification of an inverted bell-shaped relationship between the Tm values of monoenoic phosphatidylcholines and the different positions of the cis-double bond along the sn-2 acyl chain should come as no surprise, since a similar but not identical relationship with the lowest Tm value occurring at the Δ bond position of C(10) has also been observed for the lipid bilayers of a different series of chemically distinct C(18):C(18:1Δn)PE (23Wang Z. Lin H. Li S. Huang C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 23491-23499Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). For comparison, the statistical least squares line best fit to the calorimetric data obtained with C(18):C(18:1Δn)PE is presented in Fig. 2 as a dotted line. We have semisynthesized five additional series of sn-1 saturated/sn-2 monounsaturated phosphatidylcholines, and the aqueous dispersions prepared from these five series of lipids have been subsequently studied calorimetrically. Within each of the five series, the sn-1 acyl chain length is increased stepwise by two methylene units, but the chemical composition of the sn-2 acyl chain is fixed. Fig. 3 illustrates the second DSC heating scans for aqueous dispersions of four lipid samples, which represent one of the five series of monoenoic lipids under study. In this series of examples, the sn-1 acyl chains of the four lipids are derived from stearic, arachidic, behenic, and lignoceric acids, respectively, whereas the sn-2 acyl chains are derived commonly from gondoic acids or 11-eicosenoic acids (20:1Δ). Fig. 3 shows clearly a distinct gel to liquid-crystalline phase transition exhibited by each sample. In this figure, the Tm and ΔH values associated with the endothermic transition are observed to increase progressively with increasing sn-1 acyl chain length. Among the four lipid species shown in Fig. 3, C(20):C(20:1Δ)PC is the only one that has been studied previously by DSC(24Keough K.M.W. Giffin B. Kariel N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1987; 902: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The Tm and ΔH values obtained from Fig. 3 for C(20):C(20:1Δ)PC are 19.8°C and 7.5 kcal/mol, respectively, which are comparable to those reported in the literature (24Keough K.M.W. Giffin B. Kariel N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1987; 902: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Aqueous lipid dispersions prepared from four other series of sn-1 saturated/sn-2 monounsaturated phosphatidylcholines in which the sn-2 acyl chains are derived from petroselenic, oleic, erucic, and nervonic acids have also been studied calorimetrically. The thermodynamic data (Tm, ΔH, ΔS, and ΔT) associated with the gel to liquid-crystalline phase transition exhibited by aqueous dispersions prepared individually from these lipids and lipids of the first series (Fig. 3) are listed in Table 1. In Fig. 4, the Tm value is plotted against the total number of carbon atoms in the saturated sn-1 acyl chain for each of these monoenoic lipids. Clearly, the Tm value is observed to increase with increasing total number of carbon atoms in the sn-1 acyl chain for all five series of monoenoic lipids. This general trend reflects that an increase in the sn-1 acyl chain length is accompanied by an increase in the stability of the lipid bilayer in the gel state. Upon a closer inspection of Fig. 4, the Tm curves for C(X):C(18:1Δ9)PC, C(X):C(20:1Δ)PC, C(X):C(22:1Δ)PC, and C(X):C(24:1Δ)PC show that the larger the number of carbon atoms that can be found in the sn-2 acyl chain, the higher the Tm curve for a given lipid series. However, the correlation between the Tm curve and the total number of carbon atoms in the sn-2 acyl chain, based on the shape of the Tm curve, is not perfect. Furthermore, the Tm curve exhibited by aqueous dispersions prepared from the series of C(X):C(18:1Δ6)PC, shown in Fig. 4, appears to be completely out of place among other Tm curves. Recall the chain melting studies of a homologous series of lipids with different positions of the Δ bond (Fig. 2); the misplaced curve shown in Fig. 4 is thus most likely the result of the influence of the position of the Δ bond. In the case of C(X):C(18:1Δ6)PC, the Δ bond is positioned three C-C bond lengths away from C(10), the geometric center of the linear segment of sn-2 acyl chain. The Δ bond in the series of C(X):C(18:1Δ9)PC, however, lies commonly at the geometric center of their sn-2 acyl chains. In fact, the other two series of lipids also have their Δ bonds located at or near the geometric center of the sn-2 acyl chains. In summary, experimental data shown in Fig. 4 indicate that the Tm value of the lipid bilayer comprised of sn-1 saturated/sn-2 monounsaturated phosphatidylcholines depends on the total number of carbon atoms in both acyl chains as well as the position of the Δ bond along the sn-2 acyl chain. The ΔH values exhibited by various sn-1 saturated/sn-2 monounsaturated phosphatidylcholines can be grouped according to the total number of carbon atoms in the two acyl chains of the lipid structure. The results are given in Table 2. They show that the ΔH value does not, within the large experimental error, vary greatly for each member of the same group with a common molecular weight (or total number of carbon atoms). The role of nucleotides in activated RNA polymerase II transcription was studied. Permanganate footprinting confirmed that there is a strict nucleotide requirement for forming open promoter complexes that cannot be overcome by the addition of a dinucleotide primer corresponding to the start site sequence. However, higher concentrations of other nucleoside triphosphates can substitute for ATP in catalyzing open complex formation. Opening catalyzed by these nucleotides is inhibited by the ATP analogue adenosine 5′-O-(thiotriphosphate), suggesting that they may function through cross-binding to the ATP site. The KM for ATP for opening and the involvement of other nucleotides in opening differs from the characteristics reported for TFIIH helicase and C-terminal domain kinase activities. This raises the possibility that opening does not involve these activities. The results alleviate very significantly the considerable current uncertainty concerning the role of ATP in the mammalian mRNA transcription initiation pathway. However, higher concentrations of other nucleoside triphosphates can substitute for ATP in catalyzing open complex formation. Opening catalyzed by these nucleotides is inhibited by the ATP analogue adenosine 5′-O-(thiotriphosphate), suggesting that they may function through cross-binding to the ATP site. The KM for ATP for opening and the involvement of other nucleotides in opening differs from the characteristics reported for TFIIH helicase and C-terminal domain kinase activities. This raises the possibility that opening does not involve these activities. The results alleviate very significantly the considerable current uncertainty concerning the role of ATP in the mammalian mRNA transcription initiation pathway.

Several recent investigations have demonstrated that matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP-2) binds to the cell surface and undergoes zymogen activation via a plasma membrane-associated activity. The purpose of this study was to determine if association of MMP-2 with the plasma membrane also modulates the catalytic efficiency of the active enzyme. Using density gradient centrifugation, we isolated the plasma membrane fractions of two ovarian adenocarcinoma cell lines, DOV 13 and OVCA 432, previously described either to express MMP-2 or to express no gelatinolytic metalloproteinases, respectively. While DOV 13 cells contained plasma membrane-associated MMP-2 and OVCA 432 did not, both cell types were able to bind exogenous MMP-2. Furthermore, plasma membrane fractions from these cells significantly enhanced the rate of cleavage of [14C]gelatin I substrate by both MMP-2•tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases-2 (TIMP-2) complex (2.5-8-fold) and TIMP-2-free MMP-2 (5.9-fold). This stimulatory activity was dose-dependent, soluble in Triton X-100, and abolished by trypsin treatment of the membranes, but was stable to heat treatment. Plasma membrane stimulation of MMP-2 resulted in a 3.8-4.6-fold increase in the catalytic efficiency of gelatinolysis. These data suggest that, in addition to promoting zymogen activation, cell surface binding of MMP-2 may regulate enzyme activity by increasing the rate of substrate cleavage. Via this mechanism, tumor cell types that do not express MMPs (such as OVCA 432) nevertheless may be able to utilize exogenous MMP-2 to mediate proteolysis associated with invasion and metastasis. The purpose of this study was to determine if association of MMP-2 with the plasma membrane also modulates the catalytic efficiency of the active enzyme. Using density gradient centrifugation, we isolated the plasma membrane fractions of two ovarian adenocarcinoma cell lines, DOV 13 and OVCA 432, previously described either to express MMP-2 or to express no gelatinolytic metalloproteinases, respectively. While DOV 13 cells contained plasma membrane-associated MMP-2 and OVCA 432 did not, both cell types were able to bind exogenous MMP-2. Furthermore, plasma membrane fractions from these cells significantly enhanced the rate of cleavage of [14C]gelatin I substrate by both MMP-2•tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases-2 (TIMP-2) complex (2.5-8-fold) and TIMP-2-free MMP-2 (5.9-fold). This stimulatory activity was dose-dependent, soluble in Triton X-100, and abolished by trypsin treatment of the membranes, but was stable to heat treatment. Plasma membrane stimulation of MMP-2 resulted in a 3.8-4.6-fold increase in the catalytic efficiency of gelatinolysis. These data suggest that, in addition to promoting zymogen activation, cell surface binding of MMP-2 may regulate enzyme activity by increasing the rate of substrate cleavage. Via this mechanism, tumor cell types that do not express MMPs (such as OVCA 432) nevertheless may be able to utilize exogenous MMP-2 to mediate proteolysis associated with invasion and metastasis.

The human Fc receptor with low affinity for IgG (FcγRIII, CD16) is encoded by two nearly identical genes, FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B, resulting in tissue-specific expression of alternative membrane-anchored isoforms. The transmembrane CD16 receptor forms a heteromeric structure with the FcɛRI (γ) and/or CD3 (ζ) subunits on the surface of activated monocytes/macrophages, NK cells, and a subset of T cells. The expression of the glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored CD16 isoform encoded by the FcγRIII-B gene is restricted to polymorphonuclear leukocytes and can be induced by Me2SO differentiation of HL60 cells. We have isolated and sequenced genomic clones of the human FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B genes, located their transcription initiation sites, identified a different organization of their 5′ regions, and demonstrated four distinct classes of FcγRIII-A transcripts (a1-a4) compared with a single class of FcγRIII-Bb1 transcripts. Both CD16 promoters (positions −198 to −10) lack the classical “TATA” positioning consensus sequence but confer transcriptional activity when coupled to the human lysozyme enhancer. Both promoters also display different tissue-specific transcriptional activities reflecting the expected gene expression of FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B in NK cells versus polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Within the −198/-10 fragments, the sequences of the two CD16 genes have been identified to differ in 10 positions. It is suggested that these nucleotide differences might contribute to cell type-specific transcription of FcγRIII genes. Human leukocyte receptors for the Fc fragment of IgG (FcγR) play an important role in immune responses as they link the humoral immune system with cellular effector functions. Fcγ receptors represent a family of cell surface glycoproteins mediating clearance and phagocytosis of immune complexes, various forms of antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)1 and release of inflammatory cytokines (for review, see (1van de Winkel J.G.J. Anderson C.L. J. Leukocyte Biol. 1991; 49: 511-524Crossref PubMed Scopus (354) Google Scholar). Fcγ receptors have been divided into three classes, namely a high affinity class (FcγRI) and two low affinity classes (FcγRII and FcγRIII). All are members of the Ig gene superfamily. Within each group, multiple subtypes have been identified by molecular cloning. Structurally conserved extracellular domains are linked to divergent transmembrane and intracellular domains. Distinctive Fcγ receptor genes in addition to differently spliced messages from the same Fcγ receptor gene are expressed on different cell types in a tissue-specific manner generating diverse cellular responses upon interaction with IgG immune complexes (for review, see (2Ravetch J.V. Kinet J.-P. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1991; 9: 457-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (1267) Google Scholar). The low affinity receptor FcγRIII (CD16) is a 50-80-kDa membrane glycoprotein(3Huizinga T.W.J. van der Schoot C.E. Jost C. Klaassen R. Kleijer M. von dem Borne Jr., A.E.G. Roos D. Tetteroo P.A.T. Nature. 1988; 333: 667-669Crossref PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar). At least two isoforms encoded by two distinct genes, FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B, have been identified(4Ravetch J.V. Perussia B. J. Exp. Med. 1989; 170: 481-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar). An allotypic polymorphism, NA1 and NA2, has been described to be associated with the FcγRIII-B receptor isoform. FcγRIII-A is a transmembrane protein expressed on activated monocytes/macrophages, NK cells, and a subset of T cells(5Werfel T. Uciechowski P. Tetteroo P.A.T. Kurrle R. Deicher H. Schmidt R.E. J. Immunol. 1989; 142: 1102-1106PubMed Google Scholar, 6Phillips J.H. Chang C. Lanier L.L. Eur. J. Immunol. 1991; 21: 895-899Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 7Uciechowski P. Gessner J.E. Schindler R. Schmidt R.E. Eur. J. Immunol. 1992; 22: 1635-1638Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). In contrast, FcγRIII-B is a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored protein that is constitutively expressed by neutrophils and after γ-interferon (IFN-γ) stimulation by eosinophils(4Ravetch J.V. Perussia B. J. Exp. Med. 1989; 170: 481-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar, 8Perussia B. Ravetch J.V. Eur. J. Immunol. 1991; 21: 425-429Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 9Hartnell A. Kay A.B. Wardlaw A.J. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 1471-1478PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, FcγRIII-A-specific transcripts can be induced in growth-arrested human mesangial cells by IFN-γ(10Radeke H.H. Gessner J.E. Uciechowski P. Mägert H.-J. Schmidt R.E. Resch K. J. Immunol. 1994; 153: 1281-1292PubMed Google Scholar). While the GPI FcγRIII-B isoform is expressed on the cell surface without other subunits, efficient expression of the transmembrane FcγRIII-A requires the presence of the FcɛRI γ subunit and is also enhanced by co-expression of CD3 ζ, a subunit of the T cell receptors' complex (11Kurosaki T. Ravetch J.V. Nature. 1989; 342: 805-807Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar, 12Ra C. Jouvin M.-H.E. Blank U. Kinet J.-P. Nature. 1989; 341: 752-754Crossref PubMed Scopus (218) Google Scholar, 13Anderson P. Caliguri M. O'Brien C. Manley T. Ritz J. Schlossman S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 2274-2278Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). Through their differential requirements for these associated “trigger” molecules, the FcγRIII isoforms mediate different functions(14Wirthmueller U. Kurosaki T. Murakami M.S. Ravetch J.V. J. Exp. Med. 1992; 175: 1381-1390Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar). The FcγRIII-A transmembrane receptor on NK cells mediates ADCC, where it represents the only FcγR(5Werfel T. Uciechowski P. Tetteroo P.A.T. Kurrle R. Deicher H. Schmidt R.E. J. Immunol. 1989; 142: 1102-1106PubMed Google Scholar). The GPI-linked FcγRIII-B receptor on polymorphonuclear leukocytes is certainly involved in cell activation, but its detailed role is still controversial(15Hundt M. Schmidt R.E. Eur. J. Immunol. 1992; 22: 811-816Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar, 16Huizinga T.W.J. van Kemenade F. Koenderman L. Dolman K.M. von dem Borne Jr., A.E.G. Tetteroo P.A.T. Roos D. J. Immunol. 1989; 142: 2365-2369PubMed Google Scholar). The FcγRIII receptor appears to be under complex control. First, it is highly tissue-specific and is expressed on granulocytes as well as on activated monocytes/macrophages, NK cells, and some cytolytic T cell subsets. Second, only granulocytes use the GPI-linked FcγRIII-B isoform encoded by a second gene. Third, the FcγRIII-B isoform can be induced during Me2SO-initiated granulocytic differentiation of the HL60 human promyelocytic cell line. Fourth, depending on the cell type, both isoforms can be up-regulated by IFN-γ. In this study we report the cloning of both FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B gene promoters. Sequence analysis of all the cloned transcription initiation sites demonstrates structural heterogeneity through the use of alternative 5′-UT/S1 exons from the FcγRIII-A but not from the FcγRIII-B gene. We have defined the 5′ sequences necessary for promoter activity by transient transfection experiments with different parts of the FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B promoters in different cell lines. Both promoters (positions −198 to −10) displayed different tissue-specific transcriptional activities when coupled to a heterologous enhancer. These different tissue specificities are suggested to be due to nucleotide differences of the FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B genes identified at 10 positions in the −198/-10 region. Analysis of the gene structure had identified two highly conserved genes encoding the transmembrane FcγRIII-A and the GPI-linked FcγRIII-B receptor isoforms, as described recently(4Ravetch J.V. Perussia B. J. Exp. Med. 1989; 170: 481-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar). In addition, the FcγRIII-B gene coding for the GPI-linked isoform on PMN exists in two allelic forms representing the NA1/NA2 antigen system. The FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B genes have different TaqI and BamHI restriction patterns. For example the presence or absence of a TaqI site within the fifth exon is informative for the different membrane anchorages. Using the 601-bp KpnI-EcoRI probe from the transmembrane domain/cytoplasmic region/3′-UT Exon (Fig. 2A) five TaqI restriction fragments of about 6.5 (representing FcγRIIIB NA-2 allele), 3.0-3.7 (triplicate after a long run), and a weak band at about 0.2 kb (representing in addition to the 3.5 band the FcγRIII-A gene, caused by the internal TaqI site at position 733) can be detected with DNA derived from NA1/NA2 heterozygotes. This pattern was originally described by Ravetch and co-workers(4Ravetch J.V. Perussia B. J. Exp. Med. 1989; 170: 481-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar), who have shown that the T to C change at position 733 in the transcripts encoded by the FcγRIII-A gene eliminates the TGA stop codon present in the FcγRIII-B gene. Concerning the 5′ regions of both FcγRIII genes, we have performed single and double digests of genomic DNA from 15 unrelated donors (with different phenotypes according to the PMN specific NA1/NA2 antigen system) using BamHI, EcoRI, HindIII, and SalI. These Southern blot analyses proved to be consistent with the genomic organization of the two FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B genes described in (4Ravetch J.V. Perussia B. J. Exp. Med. 1989; 170: 481-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar). Therefore the BamHI site generating the 4.8-kb fragment is missing within the NA2 allele of FcγRIII-B. This BamHI site is localized about 0.3 kb within the 5′-flanking region of the NA1-FcγRIII-B and the FcγRIII-A genes, as estimated from the HindIII/BamHI double digests (Fig. 1A). The NA2-FcγRIII-B specific loss of the BamHI site co-segregates with the loss of a SalI site within the third exon EC1, also known to be NA2-FcγRIII-B gene specific (data not shown)(4Ravetch J.V. Perussia B. J. Exp. Med. 1989; 170: 481-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar). The restriction pattern of TaqI after hybridization with oligonucleotides specific for the two Exons S1 and EC1 distinguishes between the FcγRIII-A and the NA1 or NA2 FcγRIII-B genes. Irrespective of the phenotype used, TaqI demonstrated two restriction fragments of about 6 kb (FcγRIII-A, from 0.2 kb downstream to 5.8 kb upstream of the ATG) and about 2 kb (NA1/NA2-FcγRIII-B, from 0.2 kb downstream to 1.8 upstream of the ATG) (Fig. 1B). The location of these TaqI sites within the first intron and the 5′-flanking regions of the FcγRIII-A and the two alleles of the FcγRIII-B genes were observed to be different from the corresponding region presented earlier(4Ravetch J.V. Perussia B. J. Exp. Med. 1989; 170: 481-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar). Seven different recombinant clones that hybridized to the EC2 380-bp SalI-KpnI fragment (nucleotides 258-638, Fig. 2A) of the human FcγRIII-B cDNA pGP5 were identified. The two selected clones λ32 and λ31 exhibited a pattern of TaqI-hybridizing bands as expected from the determined structure of the FcγRIII-A and FcγRIII-B genes, respectively. The recombinant clone λ31 was identified as the NA2-FcγRIII-B gene without the BamHI site present in the NA1-FcγRIII-B gene. Complete restriction maps from λ32 and λ31 were constructed by digestion with BamHI, EcoRI, HindIII, and SalI (Fig. 2B). To evaluate the role of the “Ras pathway” in mediating metabolic signaling by insulin, we employed lovastatin to inhibit isoprenilation of Ras proteins in Rat-1 fibroblasts transfected with human insulin receptors (HIRc cells) and in differentiated 3T3-L1 adipocytes. Lovastatin blocked an ability of insulin to activate p21ras and mitogen-activated protein kinase. Lovastatin also significantly (p < 0.01) reduced insulin effects on thymidine incorporation and glucose incorporation into glycogen. Nevertheless, an effect of insulin on glucose uptake remained unaffected. It appears that in contrast to its mitogenic action and to its effect on glycogenesis, an effect of insulin on glucose uptake does not require p21ras activation. To evaluate the role of the “Ras pathway” in mediating metabolic signaling by insulin, we employed lovastatin to inhibit isoprenilation of Ras proteins in Rat-1 fibroblasts transfected with human insulin receptors (HIRc cells) and in differentiated 3T3-L1 adipocytes. Lovastatin blocked an ability of insulin to activate p21ras and mitogen-activated protein kinase. Lovastatin also significantly (p < 0.01) reduced insulin effects on thymidine incorporation and glucose incorporation into glycogen. Nevertheless, an effect of insulin on glucose uptake remained unaffected. It appears that in contrast to its mitogenic action and to its effect on glycogenesis, an effect of insulin on glucose uptake does not require p21ras activation. The “Ras pathway” has been identified as a key element of cellular signaling by several growth factors including insulin (1Bogulski M.S. McCormick F. Nature. 1993; 366: 643-654Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar), (2Yamauchi K Holt K Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14597-14600Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), (3Skolnik E.Y. Lee C-H. Batzer A. Vicentini L.M. Zhou M. Daly R. Embo J. 1993; 12: 1929-1936Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar),(4Buday L. Downward J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1903-1910Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Insulin activates p21ras by stimulating the activity of the guanine nucleotide exchange factor or Sos that facilitates the exchange of GDP for GTP on Ras proteins (5Medema R.H. deVries-Smits A.M.M. van der Zon G.C.M. Maassen J.A. Box J.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 155-162Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar-6Draznin B. Chang L. Leitner J.W. Takata Y. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19998-20001Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The cascade of events leading to activation of p21ras by insulin involves insulin binding, activation of the tyrosine kinase of the insulin receptor, tyrosine phosphorylation of the insulin receptor substrate-1 and She, and an association of the Grb-2-Sos complexes with either insulin receptor substrate-1 or She (3Skolnik E.Y. Lee C-H. Batzer A. Vicentini L.M. Zhou M. Daly R. Embo J. 1993; 12: 1929-1936Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar-4Buday L. Downward J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1903-1910Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). An active conformation of p21ras (p21ras-GTP) stimulates Raf-1 kinase with a subsequent propagation of the signal downstream to mitogen-activated protein kinase/extracellular signal-related and MAP1 kinases (7Moodie S.A. Willumsen B.M. Weber M.J. Wolfman A. Science. 1993; 260: 1658-1661Crossref PubMed Scopus (777) Google Scholar-8Kyriakis J.M. App H. Zhang X-F. Baneijee P. Brautigan D.L. Rapp U.R. Avruch J. Nature. 1992; 358: 417-421Crossref PubMed Scopus (974) Google Scholar). The sequential activation of these steps has been implicated in the mitogenic signaling of insulin and other growth factors (1Bogulski M.S. McCormick F. Nature. 1993; 366: 643-654Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar-4Buday L. Downward J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1903-1910Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar, 9Chuang L.M. Myers M.G. Backer J.M. Shoelson S.E. White M.F. Birnbaum M.J. Kahn C.R. Mol Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 6653-6660Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). However, the role of the Ras pathway in mediating metabolic activities of insulin remains incompletely understood. Recently, the role of Ras signaling in cellular glucose transport activity has been studied by a number of groups. Kozma et al. (10Kozma L. Baltensperger K. Klarlund J. Parras A. Santos E. Czech M.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 4460-4464Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar) demonstrated that Lys-61 N-Ras transformation of 3T3-L1 cells led to enhanced basal glucose transport and blocked insulin-mediated transport activity. Fingar and Birnbaum (11Fingar D.C. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10127-10132Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) stably transfected the cellular proto-oncogene c-raf-1 into 3T3-L1 fibroblasts and observed an enhanced expression of GLUT-1, partitioned mainly in the plasma membrane, with normal GLUT-4 distribution and insulin-mediated translocation. Introduction of constitutively activated p21ras (G12V) by microinjections into 3T3-L1 adipocytes demonstrated that p21ras mediates the insulin-induced increase in GLUT-1 expression but is not involved in the regulation of GLUT-4 (12Hausdorff S.F. Frangioni J.V. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol Chem. 1994; 269: 21391-21394Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Van den Berghe and colleagues (13van den Berghe N. Ouwens D.M. Maassen J.A. van Mackelenbergh M.G.H. Sips H.C.M. Krans H.M.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 2372-2377Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar) used insulin, EGF, and thrombin in 3T3-L1 cells to demonstrate that activation of the Ras/MAP kinase signaling pathway alone is not sufficient for the insulin-mediated glucose transport. On a separate arm of the insulin signaling pathway, two groups have now reported that inhibition of the phosphatidylinositol kinase 3 pathway with selective inhibitors wortmannin (14Okada T. Kawano Y. Sakakibara T. Hazeki O. Ui M. J. Biol Chem. 1994; 269: 3568-3573Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and LY294002 (15James G.L. Goldstein J.L. Brown M.S. Rawson T.E. Somers T.G. McDowell R.S. Crowley C.W. Lucas B.K. Levinson A.D. Marsters J.C. Science. 1993; 260: 1937-1942Crossref PubMed Scopus (606) Google Scholar) block insulin-mediated glucose transport. In this study, we examined insulin effects on glucose transport and glucose incorporation into glycogen in cells in which the Ras pathway was interrupted using lovastatin, an inhibitor of Ras farnesylation (16Casey P.J. Moomaw J.F. Zhang F.L. Higgins J.B. Thissen J.A. Recent Prog. Horm. Res. 1994; 49: 215-238PubMed Google Scholar-17Cox A.D. Graham S.M. Solski P.A. Buss J.E. Der C.J. J. Biol. Poenie M. Backer J.M. Stock J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21515-21522Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Chem. 1994; 269: 22672-22677Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we used an inhibitor of farnesylation, lovastatin, to examine the role of p21ras in the mechanism of the metabolic signaling of insulin. We observed a blunting of glucose incorporation into glycogen with no impairment of glucose transport activity. As a primary model, we used Rat-1 fibroblasts transfected with human insulin receptors (HIRc cells). Most of the results were then confirmed in 3T3-L1 adipocytes, an insulin-sensitive cell line, possessing native insulin receptors. Cell culture media and supplies were from Life Technologies, Inc. and Gemini Bioproducts (Calabasas, CA); radioisotopes were from DuPont NEN; lovastatin was from Merck. All standard chemicals were from Sigma. Insulin was a gift from Lilly, and bacterially expressed c-Ha-ras was from Dr. Alan Wolfman (Cleveland Clinic Foundation, Cleveland, OH). Rat-1 fibroblasts transfected with wild type human insulin receptors (3 x 105 insulin receptors/cells) were grown to confluence in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium-F12 plus 10% FCS plus HEPES, 50 μg/ml gentamicin, 500 nM methotrexate. 3T3-L1 fibroblasts were grown to confluence in fibroblast growth media (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium) (5.5 ml glucose plus 10% FCS, 50 μg/ml gentamicin, 0.5 mM glutamine). Two days after confluency, cells were fed differentiation media (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium) (25 mM glucose, 10% FCS, 50 μg/ml gentamicin, 0.5 mmol of glutamine plus differentiation mix (2.5 ml of 10 x PBS, 0.055 g of isobutylmethylxan-thene, 20 ml of deionized water, 250 pi of 49 mM dexamethasone, 2.5 mg of insulin)). On day 4, cells were fed adipocyte growth media (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium) (25 mM glucose plus 10% FCS, 50 μg/ml gentamicin, 0.5 mM glutamine) plus 1 μg/ml insulin. Cells were refed these media every 2 days and used around day 10-12. Confluent HIRc or 3T3-L1 cells were serum starved and incubated with lovastatin (2 μg/ml) for 24 h. During the final 4 h of the lovastatin incubation, the cells were labeled with [32P]orthophosphate (0.25 mCi/ml). The increment in percent p2 was determined as previously described (6Draznin B. Chang L. Leitner J.W. Takata Y. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19998-20001Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) with minor modifications. Briefly, precleared lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-Ras antibody Y13-259 (100 μg/ml), and the nucleotides were separated by thin layer chromatography. GTP and GDP were visualized using acid molybdate reagent, cut, and quantified by liquid scintillation counting. Determination of GEF activity was performed as previously described (6Draznin B. Chang L. Leitner J.W. Takata Y. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19998-20001Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In brief, to assay the Ras GEF, purified c-Ha-ras (500 ng, 28 pmol) was incubated with 3 pM [3H]GDP (32 Ci/mmol) in 50 pi of binding buffer (25 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 100 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 400 μg/ml chain A insulin) for 15 min at 30 °C. The complex was stabilized by addition of 5 pi of 127 mM MgCl2 for a final concentration of 10 mM. Unlabeled cultured cells were stimulated with 17-100 nM insulin or 133 nM EGF for 10 min at 37 °C, and lysates were prepared as before. Ras-GDP complex (5 pi, 50 ng) was added to 200 pi of lysate (200 pg of protein) or lysis buffer and incubated at 23 °C. At intervals, 50-pl aliquots were removed and filtered through 0.45 pM Millipore nitrocellulose filters, which were washed three times with 1 ml of ice-cold buffer containing 50 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 50 mM NaCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, and 100 pM ATP. The radioactivity of [3H]GDP bound to p21ras was quantitated by scintillation counting. A value of 0% release represents 10,325 ° 442 cpm bound. Background cpm were less than 1% of the total bound [3H]GDP. [3H]GDP binding to p21ras was confirmed by immunoprecipitation and integrity of dissociated [3H]GDP by thin layer chromatography. Confluent HIRc and 3T3-L1 cells were serum starved for 24 h and then treated with insulin (0-100 nM) and with or without lovastatin for 15 h. [3H]Thymidine was added for the final 3 h. Cells were washed (3x with PBS) and precipitated with trichloroacetic acid. Precipitable counts were solubilized and counted using a scintillation counter. Confluent cells were serum starved in low glucose (5 mM) Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium and treated with lovastatin (2 μg/ml) for 16 h. Insulin (0-100 nM) and 14C-labeled 2-deoxyglucose were added for the final 3 h. Glucose incorporation into glycogen was measured as previously described (22Thies R.S. Ullrich A. McClain D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 12820-12825Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Briefly, labeled cells were washed 3 times with PBS and then solubilized with 0.85 ml of 60% KOH at 37 °C for 30 min. The solubilized cells were transferred to glass tubes containing 4 mg of glycogen and incubated 30 min at 100 °C. Ice-cold ethanol was added to precipitate the glycogen. Following centrifugation, the pellet was resuspended in 1 ml of distilled water, and [14C]glucose incorporation into glycogen was determined by scintillation counting. Confluent HIRc and 3T3-L1 cells were refed with serum-free media and treated with lovastatin (2 μg/ml) for 18 h prior to use. Cells were rinsed and incubated in 1% Krebs-Ringer HEPES buffer with and without insulin (100 nM) and lovastatin (2 μg/ml). Glucose uptake was assessed by a 3-min pulse with 0.5 pCi/plate of 3H-labeled 2-deoxyglucose to a final glucose concentration of 0.1 mM. Cells were washed 3 times with ice-cold PBS and solubilized in 1 NaOH and 3H counts assessed by scintillation counting. Under these conditions, simple diffusion measured by L-glucose uptake was less than 5% of 2-deoxyglucose uptake. MAP kinase activity was determined as described by Heasley et al. (23Heasley L.E. Senkfor S.T. Winitz S. Strasheim A. Teitelbaum I. Berl T. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; PubMed Google Scholar). Confluent HIRc and 3T3-L1 cells were challenged with or without 100 nM insulin for 15 min, rinsed, and lysed with MAP kinase lysis buffer (0.5% Triton X-100, 50 mM /3-glycerol phosphate, 0.1 mM sodium vanadate, 2 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM EGTA, 5 μg/ml leupeptin, 0.2 units/ml aprotinin, pH 7.2). Cell debris was removed by centrifugation at 10,000 x g for 5 min, and then cell-free extracts were adsorbed to 0.5 ml of DEAE-Sephacel (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) columns, washed with three 1-ml aliquots of 40 mM /3-glycerophosphate P, 0.1 mM sodium vanadate, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM EGTA, pH 7.2, and then eluted with the same buffer containing 500 mM NaCl. Aliquots (20 pi) of column eluant were incubated for 10 min at 30 °C with 20 ml of 50 mM /3-glycerophosphate, 0.1 mM sodium vanadate, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EGTA (pH 7.2), 100 pM [y-32P]ATP (5,000 cpm/pm), 25 μg/ml cAMP-dependent protein kinase inhibitor (PKI-(5-24); (Bachem California, Torrence, CA) and 20 pM EGFR662 68l peptide (RRELVEPLTPSGEAPNQALLR) (donated by Dr. L. Heasley, University of Colorado Health Sciences Center) (23Heasley L.E. Senkfor S.T. Winitz S. Strasheim A. Teitelbaum I. Berl T. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; PubMed Google Scholar). The reactions were terminated by the addition of 10 pi of 25% (w/v) trichloroacetic acid, and aliquots were spotted on Whatman P-81 phosphocellulose (Fisher) and washed. Phosphorylated EGFR662_6gl peptide retained on filters was quantified by scintillation counting. To assess the impact of lovastatin upon hexokinase activity and the accumulation of glucose 6-phosphate, HIRc and 3T3-L1 cells were processed for glucose transport as described above. The cells were then homogenized in 0.6 M perchloric acid and centrifuged at 40,000 x g for 15 min. The supernatant was neutralized and applied to a Dowex AG 1-X8 200 mesh column (0.5 x 5 cm) followed by 5 ml of H20 and 5 ml of 1 N HC1. 20 0.5-ml fractions were collected in scintillation vials and counted as described by Heidenreich et al. (24Heidenreich K.A. Gilmore P.R. Garvey W.T. J. Neurosci. Res. 1989; 22: 397-407Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Rat-1 fibroblasts transfected with human insulin receptors (HIRc cells with 3 x 105 insulin receptors/cell) and differentiated 3T3-L1 adipocytes possessing native insulin receptors were treated with lovastatin (2 μg/ml), an inhibitor of HMG-CoA-reductase (which is an enzyme that produces mevalonate, the precursor of all isoprenoids (16Casey P.J. Moomaw J.F. Zhang F.L. Higgins J.B. Thissen J.A. Recent Prog. Horm. Res. 1994; 49: 215-238PubMed Google Scholar)), for 18-24 h prior to exposure to insulin (100 nM, 15-30 min at 37 °C). Lovastatin inhibited the ability of insulin to activate p21ras in HIRc (Fig. 1) by 90% (p < 0.001). Inhibition of Ras farnesylation with lovastatin also ablated insulin effect on p21ras activation in 3T3-L1 cells. In control cells, insulin increased p21ras-GTP association by 40%, whereas there was no effect (0%) of insulin in the lovastatin-treated cells. Although lovastatin is known to inhibit farnesylation of Ras proteins, it can also affect the signaling cascade upstream of Ras, such as an activation of guanine nucleotide exchange activity of Sos. We tested this possibility by assessing an effect of lovastatin on insulin's ability to activate GEF in HIRc cells. Insulin exhibited normal stimulation of guanine nucleotide releasing factor activity (Table I) in the lovastatin-treated cells, suggesting that the upstream steps of insulin signaling leading to an activation of guanine nucleotide exchange activity of Sos were intact in the lovastatin-treated cells. However, because of the inhibition of farnesylation with lovastatin, normal GEF activity did not result in activation of p21ras.Table 1GEF activity in control, insulin-, and lovastatin-treated cells GEF was assayed as previously described (6Draznin B. Chang L. Leitner J.W. Takata Y. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19998-20001Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and expressed as % GDP released. Insulin significantly increased (p < 0.01) GEF activity. Lovastatin had no effect, neither in control nor in insulin-treated cells. Open table in a new tab MAP kinase activity was measured in cell extracts adsorbed to DEAE-Sephacel columns and eluted with 0.5 m NaCl. The eluant was used to phosphorylate 200 pM of EGFR662_681 peptide (RRELVEPLTPSGEAPNQALLR) in an in vitro kinase assay. Consistent with an inadequate stimulation of p21ras, lovastatin-treated cells displayed markedly decreased insulin-stimulated MAP kinase activity. In control HIRc cells, insulin increased MAP kinase activity 15-fold, from 18.4 ° 2 cpm/pmol to 270.1 ° 92 cpm/pmol; whereas in the lovastatin-treated cells, insulin's effect was less than 5-fold (from 23.4 ° 0.3 cpm/pmol to 100.1 ° 0.7 cpm/pmol, p > 0.01). As anticipated, insulin stimulation of [3H]thymi-dine incorporation was significantly inhibited (p > 0.01 for both) in the lovastatin-treated HIRc and 3T3-L1 cells (Fig. 2). [14C]Glucose incorporation into glycogen was also significantly blunted in the lovastatin-treated cells (Fig. 3), suggesting that these aspects of insulin action require activation of p21ras.Fig. 3.Glucose incorporation into glycogen. A [14C]glucose incorporation into glycogen dose-response curve in HIRc cells (upper panel) and 3T3-L1 cells (lower panel) revealed a significant impairment in glucose incorporation into glycogen at 10-100 mM insulin in response to insulin in the lovastatin-treated cells (closed circles) versus the control cells (open circles) (p < 0.01 for HIRc cells and p < 0.05 for 3T3-L1 cells).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) In contrast, insulin stimulation of glucose uptake was unaffected by lovastatin in both cell lines (Fig. 4), indicating that p21ras and MAP kinase lie outside of the insulin signaling of glucose transport. To examine whether an inhibitory effect of lovastatin on glucose incorporation into glycogen was mediated by differences in the amount of glucose 6-phosphate, we measured glucose 6-phosphate in control and lovastatin-treated cells (Fig. 5). The amounts of glucose 6-phosphate were similar in these cells, suggesting the presence of normal glucose uptake and phosphorylation. Recent experiments revealed an important role of the Ras pathway in mediating mitogenic effects of insulin and other growth factors (1Bogulski M.S. McCormick F. Nature. 1993; 366: 643-654Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar, 2Yamauchi K Holt K Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14597-14600Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 3Skolnik E.Y. Lee C-H. Batzer A. Vicentini L.M. Zhou M. Daly R. Embo J. 1993; 12: 1929-1936Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar-4Buday L. Downward J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1903-1910Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). An involvement of this pathway into metabolic signaling by insulin has not been explored in detail. Since many growth factors activate p21ras proteins (but only insulin stimulates glucose uptake), it is clear that activation of Ras alone is not sufficient to promote glucose transport. This conclusion was recently supported by the observation that stimulation of the Ras pathway in the insulin-sensitive cells by EGF or thrombin was not sufficient to mimic insulin-mediated glucose transport (13van den Berghe N. Ouwens D.M. Maassen J.A. van Mackelenbergh M.G.H. Sips H.C.M. Krans H.M.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 2372-2377Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Similarly, recent findings indicated that activation of the MAP kinase in 3T3-L1 cells was not sufficient for the activation of glucose transport and glycogen synthase (25Robinson L.J. Razzack Z.F. Lawrence J.C. James D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 26422-26427Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Stimulation of the Ras pathway with stably transfected proto-oncogenic mutants of Ras and Raf-1 led to enhanced basal hexose transport in 3T3-L1 cells (10Kozma L. Baltensperger K. Klarlund J. Parras A. Santos E. Czech M.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 4460-4464Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 11Fingar D.C. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10127-10132Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar-12Hausdorff S.F. Frangioni J.V. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol Chem. 1994; 269: 21391-21394Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Kozma et al. (10Kozma L. Baltensperger K. Klarlund J. Parras A. Santos E. Czech M.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 4460-4464Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar) has stably transfected a dominant positive Ras mutant (Lys-61 N-Ras) into 3T3-L1 cells and observed that Ras activation increased basal glucose transport activity and precluded further stimulation of glucose transport with insulin. Expression of the Lys-61 N-Ras did not influence either basal or insulin-stimulated activity of the phosphatidylinositol kinase 3. Furthermore, stable transfection of 3T3-L1 cells with Lys-61 N-Ras resulted in diminution of GLUT-4 protein content and redistribution of GLUT-1 to the plasma membrane (10Kozma L. Baltensperger K. Klarlund J. Parras A. Santos E. Czech M.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 4460-4464Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). Similarly, 3T3-L1 cells stably transfected with the c-raf-1 protooncogene demonstrated an enhanced GLUT-1 content, which was found predominantly on the cell surface (11Fingar D.C. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10127-10132Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In these cells, GLUT-4 content and basal cellular localization, as well as translocation in response to insulin, were not affected. At the same time, insulin stimulated glucose uptake only 1.2-fold in the transfected cells, which was significantly less than a 16-fold stimulation seen in control cells. This decrease was due to a greatly enhanced basal glucose uptake. Similar results were obtained in 3T3-L1 cells microinjected with constitutively active or dominant negative p21ras (12Hausdorff S.F. Frangioni J.V. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol Chem. 1994; 269: 21391-21394Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The proto-oncogene, p21ras (12Hausdorff S.F. Frangioni J.V. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol Chem. 1994; 269: 21391-21394Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). appears to mediate insulin effect on GLUT-1 expression but exerted no influence on translocation of GLUT-4 (10Kozma L. Baltensperger K. Klarlund J. Parras A. Santos E. Czech M.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 4460-4464Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 11Fingar D.C. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10127-10132Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar-12Hausdorff S.F. Frangioni J.V. Birnbaum M.J. J. Biol Chem. 1994; 269: 21391-21394Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, it appears that constitutively active Ras or Raf enhances basal glucose uptake primarily as a result of increased expression of GLUT-1. The present experiments demonstrate that an acute inhibition of Ras does not influence glucose transport, suggesting that within this time frame, stimulation of Ras with insulin lies outside the signaling pathway linking insulin receptor with glucose transport. In contrast, recent reports demonstrating ablation of insulin-mediated glucose transport with specific inhibitors of phosphatidylinositol kinase 3 (13van den Berghe N. Ouwens D.M. Maassen J.A. van Mackelenbergh M.G.H. Sips H.C.M. Krans H.M.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 2372-2377Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar,15James G.L. Goldstein J.L. Brown M.S. Rawson T.E. Somers T.G. McDowell R.S. Crowley C.W. Lucas B.K. Levinson A.D. Marsters J.C. Science. 1993; 260: 1937-1942Crossref PubMed Scopus (606) Google Scholar, 26Cheatham B. Vlahos C. Cheatham L. Wang L. Blenis J. Kahn C.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 4902-4911Crossref PubMed Scopus (1000) Google Scholar) indicate a role of phosphatidylinositol kinase 3 in glucose transport activation. Conceivably, metabolic aspects of insulin action receive their signals from more than one linear path of signal transduction. The ultimate magnitude of insulin action may, thus, depend upon normal function and proper integration of these “redundant” pathways. In contrast to its minimal involvement with glucose transport, the Ras pathway appears to be extremely important for insulin effects on thymidine incorporation and glucose incorporation into glycogen. Assuming linear propagation of the insulin signaling from Ras to MAP kinase to glycogen synthase (other intermediates are omitted for clarity), these results are not surprising. Lovastatin inhibits activation of Ras and MAP kinase, with a resultant suboptimal stimulation of glucose incorporation into glycogen. The presence of normal glucose uptake and normal amounts of glucose 6-phosphate suggest that changes in glycogen synthase phosphorylation state are likely responsible for a decrease in its activity. Interestingly, that in the lovastatin-treated cells, insulin was still capable of activating MAP kinase despite almost complete absence of its effect on Ras. Since the MAP kinase activity assay does not differentiate among the members of the MAP kinase family, these results indicate that activation of certain MAP kinases by insulin may occur outside of Ras, supporting an existence of redundant pathways. In summary, it appears that certain aspects of the metabolic insulin signaling, such as glucose transport, may not require p21ras activation. Thus, diversification of insulin signaling into metabolic and mitogenic pathways occurs both upstream and downstream of p21ras. Recognition of divergent mechanisms of insulin signaling with regard to glucose transport versus other metabolic pathways, such as glycogen synthesis, may facilitate better understanding of clinical syndromes associated with resistance to glucose transport and enhanced glycogen synthesis (27Clore J.N. Blackard W.G. Diabetes. 1994; 43: 256-262Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar) or vice versa. We thank Gloria Smith for excellent secretarial assistance.

Stimulation of rat pancreatic acinar cells with cholecystokinin (CCK) is known to result in a significant inhibition of CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase (CT), a rate-limiting enzyme in phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis. Immunoprecipitation of CT from 32P-labeled acinar cells revealed that CCK treatment also caused a marked reduction in CT phosphate levels. The effects of CCK were maximal over 60 min and dependent on concentration, exhibiting an EC50 of 800 pM. Other calcium mobilizing secretagogues such as carbamylcholine (100 μM) and bombesin (10 nM) also reduced CT phosphate levels to 20 and 39% of control, respectively. Treatment of cells with thapsigargin and/or 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate established that a combination of increased intracellular Ca2+ and protein kinase C activation was necessary to decrease phosphorylated CT content. Conversely, secretin (10 nM) or 8-(4-chlorophenylthio)-cAMP (100 μM) added alone had no effects. Use of the compound JMV-180 indicated CCK was acting through the low affinity state of the CCKA receptor to reduce CT phosphate levels. Further, the decrease in phosphorylated CT caused by CCK was blocked by the phosphatase inhibitors okadaic acid (3 μM) and calyculin A (100 nM). Finally, immunoblotting from whole cell lysates revealed CT was partially degraded in response to CCK, providing a novel mechanism by which the inhibition of CT enzyme activity occurs in response to the hormone. Moreover, this degradation was also blocked by a phosphatase inhibitor. These data suggest that the dephosphorylation of either CT itself or some other regulatory molecule(s) which mediates the CCK-induced protease activation may play a central role in reducing CT enzyme levels in acinar cells. INTRODUCTIONPhosphatidylcholine metabolism in mammalian cells is thought to play a significant role in the production of the cellular messenger diacylglycerol(1Exton J. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 1-4Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Evidence for this in pancreas arises from studies utilizing acini that were prelabeled with [3H]choline (2Matozaki T. Williams J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 14729-14734Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) or [3H]myristic acid (3Rivard N. Rydzewska G. Lods J.-S. Martinez J. Morisset J. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; 266: G62-G70PubMed Google Scholar) demonstrating an activation of phospholipase C and D by secretagogues such as cholecystokinin (CCK), 1The abbreviations used are: CCKcholecystokininCTCTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferaseCHOChinese hamster ovary cells[Ca2+]free ionized intracellular calciumTPA12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetateCPT-8-(4-chlorophenylthio)-PAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. carbamylcholine, and bombesin. Similarly, it has also been shown that carbamylcholine treatment of acini which were prelabeled with [14C]glycerol resulted in a significant decrease in the levels of [14C]phosphatidylcholine(4Rubin R.P. Hundly T.R. Adolf M.A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1133: 127-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Recently, a detailed investigation of the CDP-choline biosynthetic pathway in acinar cells revealed that these agonists actually inhibited phosphatidylcholine synthesis by reducing choline uptake into cells and by inhibiting activity of the rate-limiting enzyme CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase (EC 2.7.7.15) (CT)(5Matozaki T Sakamoto C. Nishisaki H. Suzuki T. Wada K. Matsuda K. Nakano O. Konda Y. Nagao M. Kasuga M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22246-22253Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because CT was inhibited by CCK treatment and this inhibition was blocked by calmodulin antagonists, it was proposed that phosphorylation of CT by a calcium-calmodulin-activated kinase led to its inhibition(5Matozaki T Sakamoto C. Nishisaki H. Suzuki T. Wada K. Matsuda K. Nakano O. Konda Y. Nagao M. Kasuga M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22246-22253Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).CT activity is regulated by a number of factors in mammalian cells (reviewed in Kent(6Kent C. Prog. Lipid Res. 1990; 29: 87-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). While the enzyme is present in both cytosolic and membrane-associated cell fractions, it is the membrane bound form that appears to be most highly active(6Kent C. Prog. Lipid Res. 1990; 29: 87-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). Phosphorylation is also believed to play an essential role in regulating CT. Initial evidence for this came from the finding that, in the presence of phosphatidylcholine vesicles, phosphorylation of CT in vitro by protein kinase A significantly inhibited CT activity(7Sanghera J.S. Vance D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 1215-1223Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Immunoprecipitation of CT from Hela cells later established that the enzyme was in fact phosphorylated in vivo(8Watkins J.D. Kent C. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 2190-2197Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). More recently, it was demonstrated that the addition of exogenous phospholipase C to Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells produced a marked dephosphorylation of CT which coincided with its translocation from cytosolic to membrane-associated fractions and its subsequent activation(9Watkins J.D. Kent C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21113-21117Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Similar results were also reported in HeLa cells that had been stimulated with oleate(10Wang Y. MacDonald J.I.S. Kent C. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 5512-5518Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The observation that the phosphatase inhibitor okadaic acid blocked both translocation and activation of CT in CHO cells suggested that these events were mediated by dephosphorylation of CT(9Watkins J.D. Kent C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21113-21117Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, a recent in vitro study utilizing membranes from oleate- and phospholipase C-treated hepatocytes suggested that dephosphorylation of CT is not a prerequisite for its translocation but rather occurs after insertion into the membrane(11Houweling M. Jamil H. Hatch G.M. Vance D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7544-7551Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, although the precise mechanism(s) by which CT is regulated in cells is uncertain, it seems clear that phosphorylation plays a substantial role in modulating the activity of this enzyme.To date, studies investigating the regulation of CT have utilized a number of approaches in cultured cells to modulate the enzyme, such as treatment with exogenous phospholipase C(9Watkins J.D. Kent C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21113-21117Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), oleate(10Wang Y. MacDonald J.I.S. Kent C. J. Biol.
